Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I stood in the crowded room, balancing a glass of water and a plate of snacks, trying to blend in at the networking event. As a lawyer, I was used to fielding questions, but when a friendly acquaintance leaned in and asked, “So, what’s the real story behind your latest client?” I felt the familiar pressure of confidentiality tighten around me. I smiled, deflecting, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from the volunteer coordinator: “URGENT—new procedures must be followed tonight or we risk shutting down the service.” My mind raced. I was expected to uphold the strictest ethical standards as a lawyer, never revealing a client’s details, not even in passing. But as a volunteer, I was also expected to be immediately responsive, to follow every directive without delay. The two worlds collided in that moment—one demanding silence, the other demanding action. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, my heart pounding as I tried to figure out how to honor both without letting anyone down.
